results.title: Life on a string = Bian zou bian chang [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Chen Kaige, Donald Ranvaud, Beijing Film Studio, China Film Co-Production Corporation, Pandora Films and Serene Productions
results.brief_description: A blind musician has sustained himself with the belief that his blindness can be cured, but only after he has broken 1000 strings on his sanxian (a traditional three-stringed guitar). Although he has broken 995 he is now an old man approaching death who continues to roam the countryside with his restless young disciple promoting peace and harmony. This is not a conventional narrative, but a fable with an epic quality which explores the chasm between faith and magic, authority and disobedience, sacrifice and consummation. Kaige sees it as a plea for the rejuvenation of Chinese culture, civilization and identity, a plea which the Chinese authorities saw to be in some way subversive since they banned the film’s circulation in China. Cast includes Liu Zhongyuan, Huang Lei, Xu Qing. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Lin family shop = Linjia puzi [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Shui Hua, Li Kan, Shih Ping and Peking Film Studio
results.brief_description: At the centre of the story is a small-time merchant’s struggle for financial survival in a provincial town in the early 1930s. The novel by Yuan Chu and Mao Tun from which it was adapted came out of the May 4th Movement and has been described as ‘a lament for the patriotic bourgeoisie suffering from economic hardship of foreign competition’. Literature from this politically radical and western influenced movement became the subject of popularisation on the screen in the 1950s (see also Early Spring). Most pre-1949 filmmakers had been part of this cultural strain (see Street Angel). ‘The Lin Family Shop’ is regarded as the best of such fifties adaptations. The period is carefully evoked but the filmmakers were aware of the need to prevent audience identification with the shopkeeper who remains an understandable (if hardly sympathetic) figure. A narrator at the end provides the ‘right perspective’. Cast includes Wei Wei, Hsieh Tien, Han Tao. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Country teachers = Fenghuang qin [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: He Qun, Tianjin Film Studio and Xiaoxiang Film Studio
results.brief_description: With many small villages in rural China lacking funding for education, country teachers are hired with poor salaries and limited benefits. The national government encourages young teachers from the city to volunteer their services in these rural areas to overcome teaching shortages. This touching and sensitive film focuses on the efforts of one such dedicated young teacher to gain government funding to attract more qualified teachers to her small village school. Set in a remote, mountainous region of China, the film documents daily life in the village, through the teacher’s evolving relationship with the local children and elders. Cast includes Li Baotian, Ju Xue, Xiu Zongdi and Wang Xueqi. (Awards: Best Feature Film, Best Actor at the 14th Golden Rooster Awards 1994.) In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Evening bell = Wang zhong [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Wu Ziniu and August First Film Studio
results.brief_description: In China, shortly after the Japanese surrender at the end of World War II, a small group of Chinese soldiers encounter a large group of starving Japanese soldiers hiding in a remote cave. Cut off from outside contact, they do not know that the war is over. There follows a tense standoff, as the Chinese soldiers try, unsuccessfully, to convince the Japanese to surrender. This intense saga is conveyed in a taciturn, almost abstract, symmetrical style which never plays up the sensationalism of the subject nor privileges a particular point-of-view. Rather Ziniu lets the images provide eloquent testimony to the cruelty and violence that ensues. One of the 5th Generation of contemporary Chinese film directors, Wu Ziniu won the Silver Bear Award at the 19th Berlin International Film Festival for “Evening bell”. Cast includes Tao Zeru, Zhao Qi, Peipei Chong and Sun Min. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Woman demon human = Ren Gui Qing [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Huang Shuqin and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description: Directed by one of China’s most prominent female directors this highly expressionistic, psychological drama, based on a true story, focuses on the unconventional career of a famous Chinese Opera actress. Told in flashbacks, the film traces her life on the stage from the 1950s to the 1980s. The initial hostility she receives from the public for embracing male roles, turns to admiration when, defying traditions and conventions, she becomes the first woman to play the lead male role in the Peking Opera. She becomes famous in her role as Zhong Kui, a great mythical character of Chinese theatre. The character gradually takes on a life of its own becoming an alter ego and sounding board for the actress. Impressive performances and cinematographic artistry combine to create a powerful, visually stunning tale. Cast includes Xu Shouli and Li Baotian. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Hibiscus town = Furong zhen [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Xie Jin and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description: A romantic melodrama which follows the fortunes of a bean curd seller, Hu Yuyin, through the political turmoil of the early sixties, the purges at the height of the Cultural Revolution in the mid-sixties and the end of mass persecution and rehabilitation of ‘rightists’ in the late seventies. The film spans the period by honing in on Hu’s life in three years (1963, 1966, 1979). Hu, as a small businesswoman, is the target for the hardline militants but she is a survivor. She forms a relationship with Qui, reviled by the militants. Hu and Qui are branded as a ‘black couple’ and reduced to street sweepers. This is veteran director Xie Jin’s attempt to answer the challenge of the ‘Fifth Generation’ filmmakers by making a film with a critical edge. It was a popular success in China. Cast includes Liu Xiaoquing, Jiang Wen and Zheng Zaishi. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Lapis
results.brief_description: An experimental film composed of elaborate shifting patterns created by analogue computer accompanied by the sitar music of Ravi Shankar. The shifting kaleidoscope patterns, mandalas and starbursts are organised through the use of geometry and repetitions of detail. To the ancient alchemists Lapis was a kind of ‘philosopher’s stone’ or aid to meditation.

results.title: The End of the affair
results.creator_credit: Neil Jordan, Stephen Woolley and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: During the Second World War, English novelist Maurice Bendrix (Ralph Fiennes) conducted a five year, illicit affair with a married woman (Julianne Moore). Embittered and bewildered by his lover’s abrupt disappearance after a bomb attack, Maurice has the opportunity to re-enter Sarah’s life after he encounters her husband, Henry (Stephen Rea), shortly after the war. Henry, who maintains a platonic relationship with his wife, suspects that she is having an affair and appeals to Maurice to help him find the truth. Overwhelmed by jealousy, Maurice enlists the services of a private detective on the pretext that he is helping Henry. As the film flashes between the present and the past, the motives for Sarah’s actions are gradually revealed. Graham Greene denied that his novel was based on his own affair with Catherine Walston, despite dedicating it to ‘C’ and giving Sarah’s husband the same name as Catherine’s husband. Cast includes Ian Hart and Jason Isaacs. Music composed and conducted by Michael Nyman. Editing, Tony Lawson. Cinematography, Roger Pratt. Written for the screen by Neil Jordan.

results.title: In praise of love = Eloge de l'amour
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Avventura Films, Les Films Alain Sarde and Studio Canal+
results.brief_description: In the first part of ‘In Praise of love’ a man is intent on auditioning actors for a film he is making on the relationship between a man and a woman who met in the Resistance to fascism in World War Two. Filmed in stark contrasts of black and white, the film within a film takes second place to philosophical mediations on the replacement of “history by technology” and the displacement of “politics by gospel”. In the film’s last third, the stock changes from black and white film to digital video and the colours have the vividness and expression of post-impressionist painting. An elderly couple are being courted by Hollywood executives to sell their story of meeting in the Resistance and surviving the Holocaust. Their antagonistic grand-daughter, reminding them that Schindler’s widow did not share in the wealth generated by Spielberg’s film of ‘Schindler’s List’, argues against the monolithic tendency of Hollywood to exchange in, profit from, and trivialise the lived experience of others. She also reminds us that her grandparents’ history mirrors that of French philosopher Simone Weil, whose social humanism is of no interest to the business people from Los Angeles. What does all this have to do with love? ‘In Praise of love’ reminds us that not only did Jean-Luc Godard re-invent the grammar of film but that he is also one of cinema’s great romanticists. The discordant sounds and jump-cuts of his earlier films have given way to a more mediative mise-en-scene, but his experimentation with sound and image are still provoking and exciting. This film is a philosophical essay on the changing faces of love, an argument against Hollywood’s monopoly of the image, a melancholy ode to a vanishing Paris, an examination on age, passion and politics, and a celebration of the possibilities in both film and video. At the twilight of his life, Godard has created an ode that still argues for the importance and value in something called history, in something called cinema. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Time after time
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Meyer, Herb Jaffe, Orion Pictures Corporation and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: An extraordinary premise lies at the heart of this fantasy thriller: in nineteenth century London, H.G. Wells (Malcolm McDowell) invents a time machine and inadvertently transports himself as well as the notorious Jack The Ripper (David Warner) to modern day San Francisco. What follows is at turns comic and terrifying as fish-out-of-water Wells seeks out the blood thirsty killer whose brutal rampage continues across the city. Whilst on the surface this picture makes innovative use of the quirks of time travel; underneath, “Time after time” investigates the utopian visions of a nineteenth century idealist as compared to the reality of twentieth century America; a society where Jack The Ripper finds himself thoroughly at home. Cast also includes Mary Steenburgen.

results.description: An extraordinary premise lies at the heart of this fantasy thriller: in nineteenth century London, H.G. Wells (Malcolm McDowell) invents a time machine and inadvertently transports himself as well as the notorious Jack The Ripper (David Warner) to modern day San Francisco. What follows is at turns comic and terrifying as fish-out-of-water Wells seeks out the blood thirsty killer whose brutal rampage continues across the city. Whilst on the surface this picture makes innovative use of the quirks of time travel; underneath, “Time after time” investigates the utopian visions of a nineteenth century idealist as compared to the reality of twentieth century America; a society where Jack The Ripper finds himself thoroughly at home. Cast also includes Mary Steenburgen.
